title: Bold Condensed: Uncorporate
content:
This looks like Mecanorma's British Inserat, but not quite....  
Any ideas?  
Thanks!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Screen Shot 2015-02-24 at 6.14.24 PM.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202015-02-24%20at%206.14.24%20PM.jpg) | 76.48 KB |
author: Richard Hunt

comments.content: **[Compacta](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=ITC%20%2F%20%28Commercial%29&ffam=Compacta%20Std%20-%20Regular&fid=00115af27ba4b5e60e6f94ab4aab72d5&fsize=60&text=UNCORPORATE%20IDENTITY&fit=1)** is quite close - if not an exact match
Yes, thanks, that's close, in some ways closer than the British Inserat, in other ways not. The narrow diagonal on the N is unusual.

Confirming Fivos' suggestion of Compacta, any version but [Linotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/compacta-lt) or [Monotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/compacta). I can't see the differences between your sample and for instance, Scangraphic [Compacta Sh](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/compacta-sh).  
When you talk about the unusual narrowness of /N diagonal, maybe you refer to those [inktraps in the diagonal armpits](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/compacta-lt/compacta-com/glyphs.html#glyphs/532517/49) which the [Scangraphic version](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426052037/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/compacta-sh/regular/glyphs.html#glyphs/254143/97) does not have...
Yes, thanks, I think the Compacta Sh is perfect
